page.title: International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 3: Line 3:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}}
â
'''International reactions to the [[2011 Egyptian protests]]''' refer to external responses to the events that took place in Egypt between 25 January and 10 February 2011. The reactions have generally been either measured or supportive of the [[Egyptian people]], with most governments and organisations calling for non-violent responses on both sides and peaceful moves towards reform. Whilst the protesters have been calling for [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] to step down immediately,<ref>{{cite news|author=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah|title=Mubarak Says He Will Not Seek Re-Election|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/1/massive-crowds-across-egypt-demand-mubaraks-ouster/?page=|accessdate=2 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Washington Times]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref> most foreign governments have stopped short of this demand, due to [[Realpolitik]]{{or|date=February 2011}} concerns about the consequences of a power vacuum on the stability of [[Egypt]] specifically and to the wider [[Middle East]] as a whole. Some Middle Eastern leaders expressed support for Mubarak. Meanwhile many governments issued [[travel advisory|travel advisories]] and evacuated their citizens from the country.
+
'''International reactions to the [[2011 Egyptian protests]]''' refer to external responses to the events that took place in Egypt between 25 January and 10 February 2011. The reactions have generally been either measured or supportive of the [[Egyptian people]], with most governments and organisations calling for non-violent responses on both sides and peaceful moves towards reform. Whilst the protesters have been calling for [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] to step down immediately,<ref>{{cite news|author=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah|title=Mubarak Says He Will Not Seek Re-Election|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/1/massive-crowds-across-egypt-demand-mubaraks-ouster/?page=|accessdate=2 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Washington Times]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref> most foreign governments have stopped short of this demand, due to [[Realpolitik]] concerns about the consequences of a power vacuum on the stability of [[Egypt]] specifically and to the wider [[Middle East]] as a whole. Some Middle Eastern leaders expressed support for Mubarak. Meanwhile many governments issued [[travel advisory|travel advisories]] and evacuated their citizens from the country.
The protests captured worldwide attention in part due to the increasing use of [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], [[YouTube]], and other [[social media|social-media]] platforms, which empowered activists and onlookers to communicate, coordinate, and document the events as they occur. Many countries experienced their own solidarity protests in support of the Egyptians. As the levels of meta-publicity increased, the Egyptian government stepped up [[Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests#Media censorship and circumvention|efforts to limit Internet access]], especially to social media. In response there has been [[hacktivism]], with global groups attempting to provide alternative communication methods for the Egyptians.
The protests captured worldwide attention in part due to the increasing use of [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], [[YouTube]], and other [[social media|social-media]] platforms, which empowered activists and onlookers to communicate, coordinate, and document the events as they occur. Many countries experienced their own solidarity protests in support of the Egyptians. As the levels of meta-publicity increased, the Egyptian government stepped up [[Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests#Media censorship and circumvention|efforts to limit Internet access]], especially to social media. In response there has been [[hacktivism]], with global groups attempting to provide alternative communication methods for the Egyptians.
Line 179: Line 179:
In London, fifty protesters outside the Egyptian embassy called for Mubarak's regime to resign.<ref name="protests">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/01/201112815843772129.html |title=Egypt Supporters Rally Worldwide â Protests Held Across Globe in a Show of Solidarity with Egyptian Demonstrators Attempting To Oust President|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Frankfurt]], [[Germany]], a small group protested on 29 January in the main pedestrian zone, the [[Zeil]], to show their support for the Egyptian people. In [[Munich]], Germans joined the Egyptians in a demonstration in [[Odeonsplatz]] asking Mubarak to leave.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} In [[The Hague]], [[The Netherlands]], 200 people protested in front of the [[Peace Palace]] against the regime of Mubarak.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of dutch headline appended next to dutch headline}} [[Staff writer]] (30 January 2011). [http://nos.nl/artikel/215312-reisbureaus-halen-toeristen-weg-chaos-op-vliegveld.html "Reisbureaus halen toeristen weg, chaos op vliegveld"] (in [[Dutch language|Dutch]]). ''[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
In London, fifty protesters outside the Egyptian embassy called for Mubarak's regime to resign.<ref name="protests">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/01/201112815843772129.html |title=Egypt Supporters Rally Worldwide â Protests Held Across Globe in a Show of Solidarity with Egyptian Demonstrators Attempting To Oust President|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Frankfurt]], [[Germany]], a small group protested on 29 January in the main pedestrian zone, the [[Zeil]], to show their support for the Egyptian people. In [[Munich]], Germans joined the Egyptians in a demonstration in [[Odeonsplatz]] asking Mubarak to leave.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} In [[The Hague]], [[The Netherlands]], 200 people protested in front of the [[Peace Palace]] against the regime of Mubarak.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of dutch headline appended next to dutch headline}} [[Staff writer]] (30 January 2011). [http://nos.nl/artikel/215312-reisbureaus-halen-toeristen-weg-chaos-op-vliegveld.html "Reisbureaus halen toeristen weg, chaos op vliegveld"] (in [[Dutch language|Dutch]]). ''[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
â
In [[South Africa]], on 4 February, approximately 300 demonstrators blocked Bourke Street, the location of the Egyptian embassy in [[Pretoria]],<ref>[[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]] (South Africa). [http://www.dfa.gov.za/foreign/forrep/fore.htm#egy "Foreign Representatives in South Africa"]. Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> in peaceful protests organised by South African trade unions, human rights groups, and Egyptians in South Africa. The demonstrators shouted slogans such as "out with Mubarak" in English, [[Afrikaans]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], and [[Arabic language|Arabic]].<ref>http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/04/s-africans-rally-support-egypt-protesters/</ref>
+
In [[South Africa]], on 4 February, approximately 300 demonstrators blocked Bourke Street, the location of the Egyptian embassy in [[Pretoria]],<ref>[[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]] (South Africa). [http://www.dfa.gov.za/foreign/forrep/fore.htm#egy "Foreign Representatives in South Africa"]. Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> in peaceful protests organised by South African trade unions, human rights groups, and Egyptians in South Africa. The demonstrators shouted slogans such as "out with Mubarak" in English, [[Afrikaans]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], and [[Arabic language|Arabic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/04/s-africans-rally-support-egypt-protesters/ |title=S. Africans rally to support Egypt protesters |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref>
On 9 February in [[Ukraine]], [[FEMEN]] activists organised a topless protest<ref>[http://femen.livejournal.com/136430.html FEMEN Livejournal, photos]</ref> in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8144289-topless-femen-activist-supports-the-egyptian-revolution-at-the-egyptian-embassy-in-kiev-photos|title=Topless FEMEN activist Supports the Egyptian Revolution in kiev|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
On 9 February in [[Ukraine]], [[FEMEN]] activists organised a topless protest<ref>[http://femen.livejournal.com/136430.html FEMEN Livejournal, photos]</ref> in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8144289-topless-femen-activist-supports-the-egyptian-revolution-at-the-egyptian-embassy-in-kiev-photos|title=Topless FEMEN activist Supports the Egyptian Revolution in kiev|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 198: Line 198:
* {{flagcountry|Serbia}} evacuated tourists and people who worked in Egypt with two flights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radio5.co.rs/portal/moduli.php?naziv=Vesti&file=clanak&sid=80297 |title=Turisti Iz Srbije Danas Se VraÄaju Iz Egipta |publisher=RADIO 5 |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vesti-online.com/Stampano-izdanje/02-02-2011/Dnevnik/114403/Srbija-evakuise--radnike-iz-Egipta |title=Vesti online / Å tampano izdanje / 2 February 2011 / Dnevnik / Srbija evakuiÅ¡e radnike iz Egipta |publisher=Vesti-online.com |date= |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Serbia}} evacuated tourists and people who worked in Egypt with two flights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radio5.co.rs/portal/moduli.php?naziv=Vesti&file=clanak&sid=80297 |title=Turisti Iz Srbije Danas Se VraÄaju Iz Egipta |publisher=RADIO 5 |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vesti-online.com/Stampano-izdanje/02-02-2011/Dnevnik/114403/Srbija-evakuise--radnike-iz-Egipta |title=Vesti online / Å tampano izdanje / 2 February 2011 / Dnevnik / Srbija evakuiÅ¡e radnike iz Egipta |publisher=Vesti-online.com |date= |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
â
* {{flagcountry|Iraq}} offered to transport its citizens in Egypt, many of whom fled as a result of the [[Iraq War|war]], back to [[Baghdad]] for free.<ref>http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/30/iraq-offers-evacuate-citizens-living-egypt/</ref> The Foreign Ministry advised their citizens to stay away from places of tension and offered to evacuate their citizens with three military aircraft.<ref name="mofairaq">[[Press release]] (30 January 2011). [http://www.mofa.gov.iq/eng/articles/display.aspx?gid=1&id=9992 "Statement of Iraqi Foreign Ministry on Status of Iraqi Citizens in the Arab Republic of Egypt"]. Office of [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iraq)|Iraq Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
+
* {{flagcountry|Iraq}} offered to transport its citizens in Egypt, many of whom fled as a result of the [[Iraq War|war]], back to [[Baghdad]] for free.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/30/iraq-offers-evacuate-citizens-living-egypt/ |title=Iraq offers to evacuate citizens living in Egypt |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> The Foreign Ministry advised their citizens to stay away from places of tension and offered to evacuate their citizens with three military aircraft.<ref name="mofairaq">[[Press release]] (30 January 2011). [http://www.mofa.gov.iq/eng/articles/display.aspx?gid=1&id=9992 "Statement of Iraqi Foreign Ministry on Status of Iraqi Citizens in the Arab Republic of Egypt"]. Office of [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iraq)|Iraq Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Ireland}} As of 3 February, the [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Ireland)|Irish Department of Foreign Affairs]] advised [[Ireland|Irish]] citizens to immediately leave Egypt and advised against travel to Egypt.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=44979 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Ireland)|Ireland Department of Foreign Affairs]]. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Ireland}} As of 3 February, the [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Ireland)|Irish Department of Foreign Affairs]] advised [[Ireland|Irish]] citizens to immediately leave Egypt and advised against travel to Egypt.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=44979 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Ireland)|Ireland Department of Foreign Affairs]]. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
Line 211: Line 211:
* {{flagcountry|Malaysia}} On 2 February the Malaysian government announced plan to evacuate its citizens. The plan, code-named "Operation Pyramid" (Malay: Operasi Piramid) was supported by three [[Royal Malaysian Air Force]] [[C-130 Hercules]] planes, a [[Royal Malaysian Navy]] auxiliary ship, which was stationed at [[Gulf of Aden]]. Malaysian flag carrier [[Malaysia Airlines]] and low-cost carrier [[AirAsia]] later announced their support of the evacuation mission and sent aircraft to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=Vanar, Muguntan; Mazwin, Nik Anis; Majid, Embun; Kammed, K. Ashraf; Tariq, Qishin; Rahim, Rahimy; Kulasagaran, Priya|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/3/nation/7930045&sec=nation | title= AirAsia and MAS on Mercy Mission| work= [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]| date= 3 February 2011| accessdate= 3 February 2011}}</ref> The first evacuees were expected to arrive on 4 February.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/3/nation/20110203141435&sec=nation |title=Egypt Crisis: Malaysian Evacuees Leave for Jeddah| work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]| date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Malaysia}} On 2 February the Malaysian government announced plan to evacuate its citizens. The plan, code-named "Operation Pyramid" (Malay: Operasi Piramid) was supported by three [[Royal Malaysian Air Force]] [[C-130 Hercules]] planes, a [[Royal Malaysian Navy]] auxiliary ship, which was stationed at [[Gulf of Aden]]. Malaysian flag carrier [[Malaysia Airlines]] and low-cost carrier [[AirAsia]] later announced their support of the evacuation mission and sent aircraft to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=Vanar, Muguntan; Mazwin, Nik Anis; Majid, Embun; Kammed, K. Ashraf; Tariq, Qishin; Rahim, Rahimy; Kulasagaran, Priya|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/3/nation/7930045&sec=nation | title= AirAsia and MAS on Mercy Mission| work= [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]| date= 3 February 2011| accessdate= 3 February 2011}}</ref> The first evacuees were expected to arrive on 4 February.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/3/nation/20110203141435&sec=nation |title=Egypt Crisis: Malaysian Evacuees Leave for Jeddah| work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]| date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
â
* {{flagcountry|New Zealand}} On 31 January the [[government of New Zealand|New Zealand government]] warned its citizens to avoid all areas with protests.<ref>http://www.1310news.com/news/world/article/176722--new-zealand-warns-of-risk-to-travellers-to-egypt-advises-citizens-to-stay-away-during-protests?ref=topic&name=City-Hall&title=</ref>
+
* {{flagcountry|New Zealand}} On 31 January the [[government of New Zealand|New Zealand government]] warned its citizens to avoid all areas with protests.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Associated Press |url=http://www.1310news.com/news/world/article/176722--new-zealand-warns-of-risk-to-travellers-to-egypt-advises-citizens-to-stay-away-during-protests?ref=topic&name=City-Hall&title= |title=New Zealand warns of risk to travellers to Egypt, advises citizens to stay away during protests |publisher=1310News |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Nigeria}} President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] recommended that all Nigerians evacuate from Egypt. Nigeria then dispatched a team to assist its citizens in leaving the country.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2011/02/nigeria-begins-evacuation-of-citizens-from-egypt/ |accessdate= 4 February 2010 |date= 2 February 2010 |work= [[Vanguard Media|Vanguard]] |title= Nigeria Begins Evacuation of Citizens from Egypt |author= Akinboade, Laide }}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Nigeria}} President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] recommended that all Nigerians evacuate from Egypt. Nigeria then dispatched a team to assist its citizens in leaving the country.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2011/02/nigeria-begins-evacuation-of-citizens-from-egypt/ |accessdate= 4 February 2010 |date= 2 February 2010 |work= [[Vanguard Media|Vanguard]] |title= Nigeria Begins Evacuation of Citizens from Egypt |author= Akinboade, Laide }}</ref>
